basics.name: Stephen Bunn
basics.label: Full Stack Engineer and Designer
basics.summary: Stephen is an experienced full-stack engineer with a specialty in sustainable code structure and web UX. He has earned his Masters degree in Computer Science from Appalachian State University over the period of 4 years up until his graduation in 2017. Most recently, he has focused his experience working to build better user experiences at Grove Collaborative as a team-lead focused on customer acquisition. Outside of work he finds himself enjoying reading up on new design practices, discovering new music, and contributing to various open-source projects (mostly his own).

work.summary: Acted as team lead of the Growth team at Grove. This team focuses primarily on supporting and improving customer acquisition by designing and producing features that entice guests to become long-lasting customers.
highlights: Lead the design and development of a standardized component library. This library was engineered to be accessible and extensible in any Vue.js-based rendering environment (SPA, SSR, static page generation).
Lead the production of auto-generated static pages based on CMS content for all customer landing pages. This increased our PageSpeed ranking from single digits to being placed in the 90s on average.
Acted as a directly responsible individual in Grove's frontend guild helping to define and estimate North Stars for front-end minded teams.
Helped to facilitate communication between stakeholders as we had continual dependencies between marketing, design, analytics, and other engineering teams.

work.summary: Worked on a special-ops engineering team focused on building solutions, investigating problem areas, and architecting systems throughout various areas of the business.
highlights: Helped to implement payment method fraud detection. Integrated with several third-party services to handle capturing payment from customers on first-time checkouts.
Constructed CMS content schemas and produce reusable presentational components to dynamically render full web pages.
Helped to establish effective code quality tooling and style guides throughout the engineering organization.

work.summary: Worked on a small team of engineers that focused on building a platform for customer-facing applications. These applications were built to provide existing customers with an improved environment for submitting and interacting with product returns.

work.position: Web Content Manager, Office of Sustainability
work.summary: Maintained the front-end of the sustain subdomain at appstate.edu. I also help to maintain the Office of Sustainability's Google presence.

work.position: Graduate Student Researcher, Department of Computer Science
work.summary: Performed research in the optimization of existing package management systems in the component, module, and software levels of package management.

work.position: NSF REU Researcher, Department of Computer Science
work.summary: Performed research in both production level testing methods and the use of sentiment analysis in data mining. Specifically perfomed sentiment analysis on textual data taken from online resources such as Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube
Imaged and distributed statewide computer systems for the NC Division of Motor Vehicles. Helped with the implementation of a new security protocol for the Triangle Transportation Management Center.

Managed the upkeep of several simple file servers. Provided customer service to clients. Contributed research for several marketing and political projects, including a statewide homeschool convention and a North Carolina House of Representative candidateâ€™s campaign.

courses: CS5110 - Design and Analysis of Algorithms

awards.title: SSTEM Scholarship Recipient
awards.summary: Awarded the SSTEM scholarship due to great performance in his studies.

publications.name: Applying Package Management To Mod Installation
publications.summary: Package management automates the discovery and installation of software that can coexist within an operating system. The methods used by package management can also address other instances where the installation of software needs to be automated. One example of this is the environment produced by third party video game modifications. An adapted application of package management practices can help to solve the difficult problem of finding and installing a set of video game modifications that do not conflict with each other. This greatly benefits the environment by allowing third party contributions to be easily installed which fosters growth in both the developer and user community surrounding the environment. This thesis presents the theory and complexities behind package management and shows how it can be effectively applied to managing video game modifications by presenting examples of software that can extract relevant metadata from video game modifications and discover conflict free installation solutions.

references.name: David Dahl
references.reference: I find it humorous that Stephen Bunn is not regarded as a Senior Engineer. His abilities are incredible. His deep understanding of both the JS and Python ecosystems are daunting. If Mr. Bunn says "this how it should be", it is based on countless hours of research *and* engineering experience. I do look forward to witnessing the trajectory of Stephen's career, as it will be incredible. If Stephan cannot solve your engineering problem, you should just give up.
